captions.text: All right. This is fascinating...

...but you don't have the money
to bring the mortgage up to date.
So, you're still going to have to sell.
I'm sorry, Ray. We got no choice.
People will come, Ray.

They'll come to Iowa
for reasons they can't even fathom.

They'll turn up your driveway,
not knowing for sure why they're doing it.

They'll arrive at your door
as innocent as children...
...longing for the past.

"Of course, we won't mind
if you look around," you'll say.
"It's only $20 per person."

They'll pass over the money
without even thinking about it.

For it is money they have
and peace they like.
Ray! Just sign the papers.
Then they'll walk off to the bleachers...

...and sit in their shirtsleeves
on a perfect afternoon.

They'll find they have reserved seats
somewhere along one of the baselines...

...where they sat when they were children
and cheered their heroes...
...and they'll watch the game...

...and it will be as if they dipped
themselves in magic waters.
The memories will be so thick...

...they'll have to brush them away
from their faces.

When the bank opens in the morning,
they'll foreclose.
People will come, Ray.

You're broke, Ray.
You sell now, or you lose everything.

The one constant through all the years,
Ray, has been baseball.

America has rolled by
like an army of steamrollers.

It's been erased like a blackboard,
rebuilt, and erased again.
But baseball has marked the time.
This field, this game.
It's a part of our past, Ray.
It reminds us of all that once was good...
...and it could be again.
People will come, Ray.
People will most definitely come.
Ray, you will lose everything.
You will be evicted.
<i>Come on, Ray.</i>
I'm not signing.

title: Field of Dreams (5/9) Movie CLIP - People Will Come (1989) HD

comments.text: Happy Opening Day, Baltimore!﻿
comments.author: Melo Smith

comments.text:
Every time I watch this movie, I tear up at this particular scene 
remembering the trips to Veteran's Stadium I took with my father when I was 
young. Sure, the Phillies' sucked but what a perfect day it always was. Hot 
dogs, peanuts, a big Coke or two and the company of my father who I only 
have memories of now. 

Happy Easter Pop!﻿

comments.text:
I don't see the Christian theme here because the movie makes it quite clear 
that Ray, his wife and his daughter as well as Mr. Mann can all SEE the 
ball players. The brother in law cannot see them and I understand that he 
can't because he doesn't believe.  The difference is that as far as I know, 
there are 7 billion people alive today who have never SEEN and some of them 
still believe.  That is totally different than this film. Ray builds the 
field because he hears the voice and immediately is rewarded for his work 
and gets to see the players. I believed for many years and was never 
rewarded, nor did I play catch with Jesus or God, nor did they tell me to 
build anything.  All they left me with is a book filled with murder and 
hate and unjust penalties for earthly mistakes. I think if the voice had 
said, "You must build it, or go to hell" the movie might have had a 
different feel. Please go read your bible, alone. We've all seen it, and 
believe me, we don't not believe blindly. ﻿

comments.author: LiberalLogic IsAnOxymoron

comments.text:
+LiberalLogic IsAnOxymoron I don't understand your second collection of 
babble. 7 billion, NSA, super powers etc. You may marvel all you want but 
it is not that difficult. If my eternal sentence was based on whether I 
believed in a God, then that God would tell me so. Very personally. He 
would not tell some Muslim, or Mega Pastor, or Catholic Priest, and then 
say, "Well, I hope those who don't get to see me, believe Fr. Joe who now 
knows." So, again, if anyone had seen God, so too would I. If Fr. Joe saw 
God, that is his business. If I was supposed to know or believe that, I 
certainly would not be expected to take Fr. Joe's word as he also claims to 
turn bread and wine into the body and blood of a 2000 year old man who 
isn't even cemented as having existed.

Funny how someone rose from the dead, and appeared to many a multitude, 
while the dead rose and walked out their graves... and yet there is no 
writing of this anywhere. None. Nowhere. It is not history, it's story. 
Much like the fairy Godmother who turns the pumpkin into a carriage, being 
that it is in a book filled with magic and unrealistic miracles, I take it 
as a story. Not history. So, unbelievable as my Super Powers may be, I 
simply do not need to talk to 7 billion to know that Cinderella is a fairy 
tale. Even if one or two or 1.5 billion said they have seen the fairy God 
Mother turn a pumpkin into a carriage, I would not believe it without being 
shown. If I did, then I should get a huge stamp on my forehead that says 
IDIOT. I choose to not get labeled with that for my belief in the 
unbelievable.
comments.author: UBBBK

comments.text:
+LiberalLogic IsAnOxymoron As our great president (cough-cough, excuse me! 
I have a cold) Obama says, "Now... Let me be clear!"  I KNOW they haven't 
seen. You are correct in that assumption. Am I judging on the fact that I 
"think" he doesn't exist? No, the God in the bible DOES NOT exist. So, if I 
know he doesn't exist, I can easily make the assumption that no one has 
seen that which does not exist.

The bible was written by men, human beings, and so they gave God "human 
traits" like he's angry, jealous and vindictive. He gave you free will but 
if you use it to not believe you will burn for eternity. That is not free 
will.

If we go to breakfast and I say, "You have free will! I give you this great 
gift so you may order freely from the menu! Anything you like... BUT if you 
order anything else besides the Moons-over-my Hammy, then I will shoot you 
in the face." Is that free will? Of course not. I have forced you to eat 
the Moons, or die.    God would know that if I know anything in this life 
it is not to trust the word of another human unless they are my best friend 
or family who has given me no reason to not believe. I grew up in the 
church. Heavy into it and believe me, the Church ONLY gave me lies, fed me 
bullshit, and hid what would make me question. I don't know the men who 
wrote the bible but I know it has been changed, books edited, added, 
removed, re-written. A book of prophesy come true when the prophesy came 
first, then the second half of the book (where the prophesy is fulfilled), 
is written with knowledge of the prophesy. Of course Jesus comes from the 
house of David cause the Old Testament says he will. That is not divine, 
it's a joke.

God wouldn't come, author some crap, then leave, then return as man, suffer 
for a few hours, claim he was the world's savior, die, then rise and author 
some more crap, then leave and hope his creations would just read the book 
filled with rape, incest, murder and improbable impossibilities and believe 
that an all good God loves and adores them but will send you to an eternity 
in flames for 80 bad years on Earth, in which his little devil boy Satan 
tempted you non-stop throughout your life. It's beyond faith. That's 
stupidity.

God did not talk to me, or you, or anyone else. If they think he did, then 
they can keep that between them and their God because he obviously didn't 
want to talk to me. I hope I made that perfectly clear. I am saying they 
have not seen God, nor do they speak on his behalf, nor do they do his work 
or know his ways.

If God exists, then here are some facts. 1. He does not write books or tell 
people to write for him.  2. He does not do stupid things like create two 
lights in the sky, the greater to light the day, and lessor to light the 
night BEFORE he creates the Sun and the Moon. 3. He is God, and can snap 
his fingers and forgive all mankind... does not need himself to be a blood 
sacrifice so come to Earth, disappear for 18 years and return to start his 
ministry for 3 years, suffer for maybe a few hours and die a fairly quick 
death and then rise again to say hi to old buddies and say he will return 
shortly then just take off for 2000 years and 4. He is so far beyond our 
human comprehension that it is funny that we try to comprehend.

comments.text:
Although a bunch of atheists will get butthurt for me pointing it out, I 
must inform that there is a Christian theme in this:

Ray's brother-in-law can't see the famous ball players, while Ray, his 
family, and Mr. Mann can see them. Why? Because they are separated into 
believers and non-believers. The believers will see the Truth, the 
non-believers will see nothing, unless they open their eyes, mind, and 
heart. It is the same here. Ray, Terrance, and Ray's wife and daughter 
believe; Ray's brother-in-law does not.﻿

comments.author: southsidesman

comments.text:
A quick online legal marketing tip:

*Even if you build it, people may not come.*

One of the most popular online marketing sayings is, "content is king."

The idea is that if you publish "great stuff" people will find and it will 
find its way to target audiences.

Sometimes this actually happens.

But most of the time, it doesn't.

And the most common reason for this isn't complicated:

*Most "stuff" just isn't very good.*

But sometimes, good stuff doesn't get found. It needs a little help.

So, in the context of legal web marketing, "great content" really means 
content that people like *and" want to share, link to and otherwise 
publicize.

That's the part that a lot of folks forget.

If you believe that your "stuff" is worthy, but it's not getting found, 
spend some time getting it in front of people who can (and are able) to 
help promote it.﻿

comments.author: Joseph Lawrence

comments.text:
Take away the steroids, the mega-contracts, the endorsements, the hot dogs, 
the beer, the souvenirs, the mascots, the mascot races, the announcers, the 
singing of the national anthem, and the arguing over balls and 
strikes...and what do you have? Baseball.

comments.author: Kelski1998

comments.text:
Yeah, you can do all of that ... but if the little town has no baseball-age 
youth among its citizens, what good is it? These parks all went into 
disrepair because there was no one around to use them.
comments.author: jackpark7927

comments.text:
but even with all the weeds, a baseball diamond can be repaired. the weeds 
can be pulled, the grass mowed, the bleachers rebuilt. and the game that 
once warmed your soul can warm your soul again. don't look at the glass 
half empty simply because a baseball diamond, think glass half full cause 
with an imperfect baseball diamond, you have a chance to repair that field 
and bring back the warm in your soul feeling, you once had
comments.author: TheRaven878

comments.text:
Do you know what's sad? Going through a little town in the middle of 
nowhere and encountering a baseball diamond that's covered in weeds, signs 
of years of disuse. Even with JEJ's speech, I will never again be able to 
warm my soul around the game I once loved.
comments.author: jackpark7927

comments.author: poshko41

comments.text:
It's that time of year again when PEOPLE WILL COME...to watch this video! 
Spring Training (and the World Baseball Classic!) is here! Once more hope 
springs eternal...even for the hopeless teams...so I say... LET'S GO METS! 
It's hopeless, yes, but there's a sort of romance in that! That's what 
baseball offers--the memories of glorious victory, of defeat with hope, and 
the romanticism of those two related magic phrases: "WORLD SERIES CHAMPS!" 
and "WAIT 'TI NEXT YEAR!" Play Ball! :D
